Noland against Seekright lessee of Cromwell. Decided, Oct. 16th, 1818, 1. Upon~4 judgment ic Ejectrnent, if execution of the Writ of habere ,faciaspos_ sesszonrm be prevented for several years by ln~ junction, tIi~ plaintiff is entitled to the Writ on motion upon a rule to shew causes without a scirefacias, provided not more than a year has elapsed since the at~ firmance, by the Court ot~ Appea's, (if the Decree dissolving th~ luJue~ ~ion and dismis~iug the Bill in Chancery. 2 In such caso, if the termlaid in the declaration has expired pending the pro, cec dings on the Injunction, the Court to which the motion is made for the Writ, of habere facias possessionem, may cause the term to be enlarged and SW&l’d tits Writ, upon a rule to sheiy cause, served upon the defendant-, AFTER a judgment in Ejectment in favour of Seek-right lessee of .TLtargaret Cromwell against Thomas ~Mi-land, the following order was made l)y the Superior Court of Frederick Coimty, on the 4th of October i 814; viz, " On the motion ot the plaintiff by his Counsel, and' " it appearing to the Court, by the Record, that this " terminated infaurntr qf the piaint~fl~ in the late District " Coart held at Wi'nchester; a~id it farther appearing to " the Court, that the defendant obtained an Injunction "to stay proceedings on said Judgment; that sai(1 case " has beei~ many years peialmg in the Court of Equliy, " and in the Court of Appeals; that both sajd Courts " decided in favour 01 the said plaintiff; and that, with- " iii the time of said litigation kept up and continued by "i~kc appeal of the defendant from Court to Court, the "term of the plaintiff's lease hath expired, a Rule is "granted the plaintiff upon the defendant to skew cause: "on Friday next, (the 5 Ui day of the present terrn,)~ " why the term in said lease mentioned should not be en- *186« larged, and the Commonwealth’s Writ of habere facias “ possessionem awarded the plaintiff, to cause him to have ee possession of his term, so to be enlarged, in the prem “ *se,s ^ie sa^ ^easc mentioned.” The Rule being served, (in proof of which an- añida» .pit was filed,) was afterwards enlarged from time -to time, for reasons appearing to the Court, until the 9th of May 1815, when it was made absolute; leave was granted to enlarge the.demise laid in the declaration, by inserting the word thirty, in the place of twenty, in the said declaration, so as to make the term of the demiso thirty one, itstead of twenty .one years; and a Writ of habere facias possessionem was awarded, to cause the plain-, tiff to have possession of his term so enlarged. To this Order the defendant obtained a Writ of Supersedeas from a Judge of this Court; stating in his Petition the. following reasons; 1st, because the said Superior Court had no power after judgment to alter the Record, even if the Judgment had been entered in that. Court; there being no clerical mistake, or any thing which should bring the case within the operation of the Acts of Jeofails:-—2d, that, if even the Court had power to permit such alteration after judgment in the same Court, there was no such power when the judgment had been obtained in another Court: and Sd, because, as more than a year elapsed from the judgment, (the District Courts having ceased to exist much more than a year be-, fore the said Rule was obtained,) no writ of possession could be sued out without a scire facias first issuing, Wickham for the plaintiff in error. Stanard contra.

The doctrine that a Court of law-will not take notice of an Injunction lias been exploded in England. Here the execution of the Writ of habere facias possessionem was intercepted by Injunction, and twelve months did not elapse, from the time when the party was at liberty to take out the Writ, before it was actually taken out. (1)

*187Wickham admitted that where the party is delayed by Injunction, he is not put to his scire fadas.(2)

Stanard, to shew the right of the Court to enlarge the term, cited Hunter v. Fairfax's devisee, 1 Munf. 218-238, and Vicars v. Haydon, Cowp. 841; in both which cases, the appellate Court itself changed the record by tnt'L.U’ging flic term. The demise in Ejectment is merely fictitious:-it is a remedy invented to try the title; is under the control of the Court, and may he modelled so as to accomplish the purposes of justice.(a)

The Court of Appeals affirmed, in January 1814, the decree dissolving the Injunction and dismissing the Bill. See 4 Mmf, 15 7,

Note. See argument in Gray's admx. v. Berryman, 4 Munf. 183-4.

3 Burr. 1295.

October IGth, 1818, the Court affirmed the Order in question.
